conclusion: Determine the minimum area of each piece of paper needed to cover the faces of the cube so the bubble is not visible.
The image shows a cube with a side length labeled as 'a' and a small bubble at the center.
The cube has a side length of 'a,' and the bubble is at the center, equidistant from all faces.
Each face of the cube must be covered completely to ensure the bubble is not visible.
The minimum area of paper needed on each face is determined by the area of the face itself.
The area of one face of the cube is calculated as \( a \times a = a^2 \).
Since there are six faces on a cube, the total area of paper needed is \( 6 \times a^2 \).
The question asks for the minimum area of each piece of paper, which is the area of one face, \( a^2 \).
The minimum area of each piece of paper is \( a^2 \).
The minimum area of each piece of paper is \( \frac{4\sqrt{3}}{9}a^2 \).
